0: Prepare and process import and export documentation according to customs regulations, laws, or procedures.
Clear goods through customs and to their destinations for clients.
Pay, or arrange for payment of, taxes and duties on shipments.
Calculate duty and tariff payments owed on shipments.
Request or compile necessary import documentation, such as customs invoices, certificates of origin, and cargo-control documents.
Classify goods according to tariff coding system.
Stay abreast of changes in import or export laws or regulations by reading current literature, attending meetings or conferences, or conferring with colleagues.
Sign documents on behalf of clients, using powers of attorney.
Advise customers on import and export restrictions, tariff systems, insurance requirements, quotas, or other customs-related matters.
Post bonds for the products being imported or assist clients in obtaining bonds.
Quote duty and tax rates on goods to be imported, based on federal tariffs and excise taxes.
Arrange for transportation, warehousing, or product distribution of imported or exported products.
Monitor or trace the location of goods.
Confer with officials in various agencies to facilitate clearance of goods through customs and quarantine.
Inform importers and exporters of steps to reduce duties and taxes.
Obtain line releases for frequent shippers of low-risk commodities, high-volume entries, or multiple-container loads.
Provide advice on transportation options, types of carriers, or shipping routes.
Contract with freight forwarders for destination services.
Apply for tariff concessions or for duty drawbacks and other refunds.
Insure cargo against loss, damage, or pilferage.
Prepare papers for shippers to appeal duty charges.
1: Analyze training needs to develop new training programs or modify and improve existing programs.
Evaluate instructor performance and the effectiveness of training programs, providing recommendations for improvement.

Plan, develop, and provide training and staff development programs, using knowledge of the effectiveness of methods such as classroom training, demonstrations, on-the-job training, meetings, conferences, and workshops.
Confer with management and conduct surveys to identify training needs based on projected production processes, changes, and other factors.
Conduct orientation sessions and arrange on-the-job training for new hires.
Train instructors and supervisors in techniques and skills for training and dealing with employees.
Develop and organize training manuals, multimedia visual aids, and other educational materials.
Prepare training budget for department or organization.
Develop testing and evaluation procedures.
Conduct or arrange for ongoing technical training and personal development classes for staff members.
Review and evaluate training and apprenticeship programs for compliance with government standards.
2: Monitor and record food temperatures to ensure food safety.
Cook foodstuffs according to menus, special dietary or nutritional restrictions, or numbers of portions to be served.
Rotate and store food supplies.
Wash pots, pans, dishes, utensils, or other cooking equipment.
Apportion and serve food to facility residents, employees, or patrons.
Clean and inspect galley equipment, kitchen appliances, and work areas to ensure cleanliness and functional operation.
Clean, cut, and cook meat, fish, or poultry.
Direct activities of one or more workers who assist in preparing and serving meals.
Train new employees.
Take inventory of supplies and equipment.
Requisition food supplies, kitchen equipment, and appliances, based on estimates of future needs.
Bake breads, rolls, or other pastries.

0: Verify compliance with international trade regulations and ensure accurate documentation for shipments.
Prepare and submit customs forms, including Harmonized System (HS) codes and applicable tariffs.
Conduct research to determine duties, taxes, and fees associated with imported goods.
Negotiate with clients to understand their import needs and provide customized solutions.
Coordinate with shipping carriers and manufacturers to ensure timely and efficient delivery of goods.
Inspect shipments for accuracy and completeness, identifying any discrepancies or issues.
Communicate with government agencies, including U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP), to resolve clearance issues.
Analyze trade data and market trends to identify opportunities for growth and optimization.
Develop and maintain relationships with clients, ensuring long-term business partnerships.
Prepare and submit export declarations for domestic shipments.
Provide customers with guidance on compliance regulations, including but not limited to customs forms, permits, and licenses.
Process and verify shipment documentation, including bills of lading, commercial invoices, and certificates of origin.
Respond to client inquiries and resolve issues in a timely and professional manner.
Attend industry conferences and seminars to stay up-to-date on regulatory changes and best practices.
Collaborate with other departments, such as accounting and operations, to ensure seamless communication and coordination.
Develop and implement trade compliance programs for clients, including audits and training.
Conduct site visits to verify manufacturer compliance with regulations and industry standards.
Prepare and submit applications for necessary permits and licenses, ensuring timely clearance of shipments.
Monitor shipment status in real-time, using technology such as customs brokers' software and carrier systems.

1: Develop and implement comprehensive training programs to enhance employees' skills and knowledge in alignment with organizational goals.
Design and deliver instructional materials, including course outlines, presentation scripts, and assessments, to support employee learning and development needs.
Conduct needs assessments to identify skill gaps and determine the most effective training solutions for teams or departments.
Evaluate training effectiveness through pre- and post-testing, surveys, and feedback mechanisms to inform program improvements.
Collaborate with subject matter experts to develop high-quality content and ensure alignment with industry standards and best practices.
Mentor and coach employees to enhance their professional development and career advancement opportunities within the organization.
Create a learning management system (LMS) implementation plan, including integration with existing HR systems and deployment of training content.
Foster relationships with external training partners and vendors to develop mutually beneficial training opportunities for employees.
Develop and maintain a training budget and track expenditures to ensure efficient use of resources and align spending with organizational priorities.
Certify and license trainers as needed, ensuring compliance with industry standards and best practices in adult learning and instructional design.
Analyze trends and metrics to identify areas for improvement in the training program and propose data-driven solutions to optimize learner engagement and outcomes.
2: • Prepare and cook meals to institutional and cafeteria standards.
• Maintain accurate inventory of food supplies and ingredients.
• Operate cooking equipment safely and efficiently to achieve optimal menu quality.
• Supervise and train junior staff members on food preparation techniques.
• Order and replenish non-perishable food items and beverages as needed.
• Ensure proper food handling and storage procedures are followed to prevent spoilage and contamination.
• Manage food allergies, dietary restrictions, and special requests from customers.
• Maintain a clean and organized kitchen environment, adhering to health codes and regulations.
• Monitor menu offerings and customer feedback to inform inventory management and menu planning.
• Prepare and serve beverages according to institution or cafeteria policies.
• Participate in food safety training and adhere to industry standards for food handling and preparation.
• Maintain accurate records of food waste, inventory, and labor hours for quality control purposes.
